q1.text: What percentage of your daily schedule is dictated by external deadlines, alarms, or societal expectations?

responses.a: Minimal external control detected. Is that freedom you feel, or are you just off-grid?
responses.b: Moderate compliance with societal rhythms. You’re playing along, for now.
responses.c: You’re tightly synced to the system. Is it comforting or crushing?
responses.d: Perfect adherence to external demands. Time isn’t yours—it’s rented out hourly.

q1.reflection: Ever notice how your schedule isn’t really your own? If you didn’t have deadlines, what would you do with your time?

q2.text: How many hours per day do you dedicate to activities with measurable outcomes (e.g., work, chores, studying)?

responses.a: Two hours? Bold. Society might call that lazy; maybe you call it living.
responses.b: Respectable effort. Just enough productivity to stay in the game.
responses.c: Impressive grind. Are you earning, or are you just burning?
responses.d: 9+ hours? Consider submitting your timesheet to the universe for overtime.

q2.reflection: Imagine if productivity wasn’t tied to your value. Would you work less, or would you work differently?

q3.text: How often do you feel guilty for ‘wasting’ time in a single day?

responses.a: No guilt? Revolutionary. Do you even own a clock?
responses.b: Occasional guilt is healthy. Just enough shame to keep you productive.
responses.c: You’re guilt-driven. Do you think about time, or does it think about you?
responses.d: Constant guilt? It’s like the system implanted a stopwatch in your brain.

q3.reflection: Who decides what counts as ‘wasting’ time? Spoiler: It’s probably not you.

q4.text: How many times a day do you check the time (via clocks, phones, or other devices)?

responses.a: Practically timeless. Are you enlightened, or just running late?
responses.b: Moderate clock-checking. You’re aware but not obsessed.
responses.c: The clock owns you. Who’s the boss—your wristwatch or your brain?
responses.d: 21+ times? Time management or time micromanagement?

q4.reflection: Why does checking the time feel so necessary? What happens if you don’t?

q5.text: When you reflect on your day, do you categorize it by...

responses.a: Meaningful moments? Do you have a secret stash of free time?
responses.b: You’re living in the spreadsheet of life. Cells filled, day complete.
responses.c: Counting waste? What if time didn’t have to be useful to be valuable?
responses.d: You’re in survival mode. Is time something you use—or something you endure?

q5.reflection: Does your day belong to you, or is it just a series of transactions with time

q6.text: Do you notice time feeling different based on the activity you’re doing?

options.a: No, time feels linear and constant.
options.b: Yes, work drags, and fun flies by.
options.d: Always, and it makes me question everything.

responses.a: Linear time? That’s the official story, but it sounds suspiciously robotic.
responses.b: Work drags, fun flies—classic capitalism. Guess which one’s prioritized?
responses.c: Ignoring time’s weirdness? That’s peak denial. Stay calm and carry on.
responses.d: Questioning time? Careful, that’s how revolutions start.

q6.reflection: If time isn’t constant, why do we treat it like it is? Who benefits from that?
